<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 303, 310, 319]]<|/det|>
Paper 1 Pure Mathematics 1  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[710, 303, 907, 320]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 384, 390, 400]]<|/det|>
You will need: List of formulae (MF19)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 419, 225, 435]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 435, 880, 632]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown.- You should use a calculator where appropriate.- You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.- Give non-exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 664, 216, 679]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 680, 732, 712]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 75.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 74, 97, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 406, 92]]<|/det|>
The function f is defined as follows:

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[405, 97, 589, 127]]<|/det|>
\[\mathrm{f}(x) = \frac{x + 3}{x - 1}\mathrm{for} x > 1.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 147, 146, 165]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 147, 344, 165]]<|/det|>
Find the value of ff(5).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 147, 920, 165]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 390, 186, 408]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 390, 400, 408]]<|/det|>
Find an expression for \(\mathrm{f}^{-1}(x)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 390, 920, 408]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 78, 92, 97]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 761, 106]]<|/det|>
A curve is such that \(\frac{\mathrm{d}y}{\mathrm{d}x} = \frac{8}{(3x + 2)^2}\). The curve passes through the point \((2, 5\frac{2}{3})\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 116, 364, 135]]<|/det|>
Find the equation of the curve.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 117, 920, 135]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 73, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 109]]<|/det|>
The second term of a geometric progression is 54 and the sum to infinity of the progression is 243. The common ratio is greater than \(\frac{1}{2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 120, 551, 139]]<|/det|>
Find the tenth term, giving your answer in exact form.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 120, 920, 139]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 148, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 920, 109]]<|/det|>
Calculate the area of the shaded region which is bounded by the arc \(CQ\) and the lines \(CP\) and \(PQ\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 87, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 73, 96, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>8</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 146, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 794, 92]]<|/det|>
It is given that in the expansion of \((4 + 2x)(2 - ax)^5\), the coefficient of \(x^2\) is \(-15\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 104, 393, 123]]<|/det|>
Find the possible values of \(a\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 104, 920, 123]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 148, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 920, 108]]<|/det|>
It is given instead that in the expansion of \((4 + 2x)(2 - ax)^5\), the coefficient of \(x^2\) is \(k\). It is also given that there is only one value of \(a\) which leads to this value of \(k\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 120, 371, 138]]<|/det|>
Find the values of \(k\) and \(a\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 120, 920, 138]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 148, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 905, 92]]<|/det|>
Find the volume of the mound at the instant when the radius is increasing at 0.1 m per second.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 88, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 79, 104, 98]]<|/det|>
<label>10</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 561, 101]]<|/det|>
The function f is defined by \(\operatorname {f}(x) = x^{2} + \frac{k}{x} +2\) for \(x > 0\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 114, 146, 133]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 114, 831, 134]]<|/det|>
Given that the curve with equation \(y = \operatorname {f}(x)\) has a stationary point when \(x = 2\), find \(k\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 114, 920, 133]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 148, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 514, 91]]<|/det|>
Determine the nature of the stationary point.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 73, 920, 92]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 510, 186, 528]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 510, 751, 528]]<|/det|>
Given that this is the only stationary point of the curve, find the range of f.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 510, 920, 528]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 148, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 816, 92]]<|/det|>
Find the area of the shaded region, giving your answer correct to 2 decimal places.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 73, 920, 92]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 148, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 774, 92]]<|/det|>
Points \(Q\) and \(R\) also lie on the circle, such that \(PQR\) is an equilateral triangle.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 104, 448, 123]]<|/det|>
Find the exact area of triangle \(PQR\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 104, 920, 123]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]
